item.title: Beyond the basics with Cloud Foundry
item.description: The advent of Docker changed the way we develop applications. Once you had written a Dockerfile and built the image, your application will run (almost) anywhere, regardless of the underlying operating system, and best of all, it just works. You can then expose ports, map volumes to persist data and deploy your image in Docker Swarm or Kubernetes (K8s). With great flexibility, however, comes greater costs, whether that is increased developer’s skillset requirements and time spent on writing multiple K8s YAML config files, or pricier services on your favourite cloud provider.
